data.title: USA TODAY
data.meta_description: The Brits play Americans like they were born here, and Bob Hoskins, who died Wednesday, was no exception.
data.text:
Three times Bob Hoskins played an American better than an American

British character actor Bob Hoskins died Wednesday at the age of 71. While he portrayed everyone from Nikita Khruschev in 2001's Enemy at the Gates to Winston Churchill in 1994's When Lions Roared, he had a knack for playing Americans better than most American actors could.

Here are three roles where he Yanked it up to great effect -- and one role that got away:

Eddie Valiant, 'Who Framed Roger Rabbit?' (1988)

Hoskins played a hard-boiled private investigator straight out of Central Casting in the beloved animated/live-action mashup:

J. Edgar Hoover, 'Nixon' (1995)

He held his own as the controversial head of the FBI opposite Oscar-nominated (and also Briton-playing-an-American) Anthony Hopkins:

Eddie Mannix, 'Hollywoodland' (2006)

Hoskins again put on an accent to play a sleazy 1950s movie-studio executive whose wife is having an affair with Superman actor George Reeves (Ben Affleck):

And one that got away -- Al Capone, 'The Untouchables' (1987)
